body: I think I have identified the problem - an update during the compaction can cause the transaction coordinator to block. It is a deadlock - no amount of waiting will cause the system to unblock.

> The data can be provided if it helps.

A minimal, reproducible example please.

Minimal code, minimal data. 

Does the example work in previous versions?
That didn't help... I'll try removing `OntModelReadOnly` usages altogether.
The NPE went away when I removed my implementation. I'll try to make a standalone example.

Tested using the branch from #1307:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/179691802-b70104ee-7232-4a00-9548-78825f4bfddf.png)

It will take a little longer to finish testing that branch, but once that's merged and released, this issue should be fixed :+1: 

-Bruno

This should be now working without Bootstrap Vue (blocker for Vue 3), and with the vanilla Bootstrap 5.2 CSS. I will keep working on and off to add more tests, especially since I had to write some custom components to replace the ones provided by Bootstrap Vue. But in case a release is necessary with this code (as it fixes one bug), it can be tested manually as well and released.

I have a separate issue to work exclusively on e2e tests, which should hopefully make Jena UI less error prone, and help with code refactoring (which unfortunately happens with some frequency in JS due to libraries, updated, security, etc).

-Bruno
Could you provide a minimal example of JSON-LD please so we're exactly seeing the same thing?

Note: there's some work for a query library, that might cover this issue. A pull request might be ready in the next days/weeks, and it'd be great to receive user feedback before a release if possible :slightly_smiling_face:

Managed to add e2e tests today too. They run similar to Selenium, but due to the way Cypress works, tests are less brittle.

Running the e2e tests will download some large dev dependencies, and video recording is disabled by default to reduce disk space, but that can be enabled to record the tests if needed.

```
yarn run coverage:e2e
yarn run test:e2e
yarn run test:e2e -- --headless --browser chrome
```

These are examples of how to run it. Without the `--headless`, Cypress will display a dialogue to choose the browser to run the tests with. You can go back in time and review what the UI looked like for each step of the test, which is quite handy when reproducing tests or user issues.

I've implemented a small JS mock server to store datasets and return some dummy data for the UI. This way we don't need to start a Docker container or something like that every time we run the tests (I found out that that helps speeding up the UI development, especially if a contributor is not familiar how to run the Jena backend.)

![Screenshot from 2022-07-20 13-26-10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/179879089-282fc6a4-5925-40ec-b51e-9a0d8003e837.png)

Test coverage is also quite good now with the e2e tests - the report below shows just the e2e tests coverage, but what's important is that it's covering the new code that I had to write to move away from Bootstrap Vue, and also that we can use these tests to write most of the new tests if needed (i.e. easy to copy-and-paste to create new tests).

![Screenshot from 2022-07-20 13-57-08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/179879242-60ff911a-0a1a-4f12-bac8-86109109e04e.png)

Ready for review @afs, whew. After this one gets merged, my next task will be to upgrade all dependencies to the latest, and start moving things from Vue 2 to Vue 3. I will need to refresh my memory on what's new, and follow their migration guide. But it should be **a lot** easier than it was to remove the Bootstrap Vue dependency from our code base.

Thanks!
-Bruno

@ramsel1508, my last commit contains an e2e test for your issue #1443. Hopefully that will prevent this issue from happening again :+1: Thanks for reporting and for the patience!

-Bruno

Dependabot proposing changes to the lock file again.

@kinow - Is this covered by your work on Vue3?

If so, a quick solution is to have an explicit resolution in `package.json`.

Alternatively, `yarn upgrade` does the following to `package.json`:
```
-    "follow-redirects": "^1.14.9",
+    "follow-redirects": "^1.14.7",
+    "nanoid": "^3.3.1",
```
and `terser` get updated to 5.14.2.

@ Jena GeoSPARQL community: There needs to be text in the ANN for 4.6.0 that highlight this change.

Draft text:

GH-1299 - The GeoSPARQL has acknowledged a mistake in the example in their document
whereby the wrong namespace was being used for "gml:".

https://github.com/opengeospatial/ogc-geosparql/pull/334

Fixing this in jena-geosparql enables working with GML from other tools but unfortunately impacts impacts existing data. Any spatial indexes need to be deleted and rebuilt.

> Fixing this in jena-geosparql enables working with GML from other tools but unfortunately impacts impacts existing data.

Existing gmlLiterals need to be migrated to the correct XML namespace

> Any spatial indexes need to be deleted and rebuilt.

... if you were previously making use of the gml in jena-geosparql


...

at least, as far as I can, tell this does not affect users that were only using wkt or the old wgs84

>@kinow - Is this covered by your work on Vue3?

Just checked and it's a transitive dependency of `@vue/cli-service`, so moving to Vue will likely fix it too, so yes.

>If so, a quick solution is to have an explicit resolution in package.json.

Normally I leave resolutions for when something is not working as expected. I think upgrading in the lock file is safe too, as others will have the same version.

>Alternatively, yarn upgrade does the following to package.json:

Interesting! Not sure why `follow-redirects` was downgraded? But if that upgrades our `terser`, then I'm not too worried as these are all dev-dependencies (not included in the final JS file).

`terser` has an issue raised against it for a insecure use of regexs which is why we got this PR from dependabot.

PR #1455 is the outcome of removing the `resolutions{}` section of package.json, then ran `yarn update`.  All the previous explicit choices seem to now pick up later versions.

I did some basic testing fo the UI and it seems to work.

Draft text v2:

----
https://github.com/apache/jena/issues/1299 - The GeoSPARQL has acknowledged a mistake in the example in their document
whereby the wrong namespace was being used for "gml:".

https://github.com/opengeospatial/ogc-geosparql/pull/334

Fixing this in jena-geosparql enables working with GML from other tools but unfortunately impacts impacts existing data. 

If you were previously making use of the gml in jena-geosparql, any use of URI prefix `http://www.opengis.net/ont/gml` needs to change to `http://www.opengis.net/gml/3.2` and any spatial indexes need to be deleted and rebuilt

----

or should we just say "delete and rebuilt" in case the user operating the system, isn't the user providing the data?
Looks like terser is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
Done with #1455.

The PR is now overall ready for review.

There is a preliminary jena-extras/jena-serviceenhancer/README.md which I will extend in the next days and the javadocs will need another pass too. There are several test cases which may also be a good starting point. Due to vacation progress is a bit slow.

For the release, I suggest a separate email message and sent by you (@Aklakan) that introduces this new feature in a way that does not have the distractions of the general coverage of [ANN].  This would be sent soon after after the AN Nand maybe also to a wider set of lists. 

And jena-site material. The link can be tweeted.

README.md in the code base isn't the easiest or natural place for users.
Superseded by #1307

Rebased. Then re-ran `yarn install`. Unit tests, and e2e tests both have passed successfully :-)

Closed the superseded issue for e2e tests, and linked this one in JIRA as well.

Started migrating the app to Vue3 to save time (not committing anything here, will stash / create a diff).

Only blocker so far: https://github.com/vuejs/router/issues/454

Other than that, got the app up and running with no warnings after poking around with `yarn`, my IDE, and reading the great migration docs the Vue devs wrote :tada:

Document can be after the release though to make impact it is better to have enough for users when you have their attention.

The next Jena release cycle is in the vacation season for many so might be more about preparation/"experimental"/"beta" then do more at the one after that (end October _maybe_).

The choice is yours of how to get the most here.

Hi, just want to give some feedback about the PR.

To keep it short, good job @galbiston - we merged the PR in our local Apache Jena Fuseki 4.6.0-SNAPSHOT deployment which provides a geospatial index on millions of geospatial geometries. Works as expected.

That indeed replaces unit tests, but so far it works for us at least. Is the lack of unit tests still a blocker for merging into main? Also pinging @afs here as he is interested as well about the current status

@afs  We're already using JTS 1.19.0 in our Jena fork - the release basically added added new algorithms (which we partially make use of) and lots of bug fixes and parser code (e.g. the GeoJSON parser now also considers FeatureCollections).
We didn't recognize any issues yet.

Tests would be ideal but given it's been used so that will do.

So probably merge this in a few days and I'll apply the @LorenzBuehmann suggestions.
Thanks for the information. It's merged and will be used in the daily development builds from now on.
Status? If there isn't anything actionable about Jena, this should be closed.
Nothing actionable right now because I'm on vacation. Might reopen later when I have time to build a test case.

> More just I trying to learn a little more about this part of the code

Brave! In terms of the jumping in at the deep end, this also has whirlpools and sharks. The thread coordination is complicated. I have to set aside at least half-days to do much work on this area to get into the mindset to make changes.

Yeah, I realized I would need a lot longer to really understand the code. But it still doesn't look too bad to understand what's going on locally (I think the hard bit is telling how these parts are used elsewhere :sweat_smile: ).

Thanks Andy!

> README.md in the code base isn't the easiest or natural place for users.

I opened a PR for jena-site with the documentation: https://github.com/apache/jena-site/pull/113
I can basically replace the README.md in `/jena-extras/jena-serviceenhancer` with a link to the doc in jena-site.

For the namespace I would prefer `se: http://jena.apache.org/service-enhancer#` with a dash (`-`) but if you insist on underscore `_` it's also fine with me. I think there is no need to make things more complex by introducing further namespaces for functions / property functions / assembers.

Should I move all IRIs introduced by the plugin to that namespace? - e.g. `se:DatasetServiceEnhancer` instead of `ja:DatasetServiceEnhancer`? This would make it more self-contained.

> `urn:base` is an illegal URN and causes a parser warning. 

Right, I now use `urn:example:base` which I hope is valid. I am making an explicit reference in the example with `model.getResource("urn:example:root")` so a relative IRI or blank node is not really helpful.
To get HTML, use parameters in the URL request: `...&output=xml&stylesheet=%2Fxml-to-html.xsl`

> For the namespace I would prefer `se: http://jena.apache.org/service-enhancer#` with a dash (`-`) but if you insist on underscore `_` it's also fine with me. I think there is no need to make things more complex by introducing further namespaces for functions / property functions / assembers.

`-` (dash) is fine.

> Should I move all IRIs introduced by the plugin to that namespace? - e.g. `se:DatasetServiceEnhancer` instead of `ja:DatasetServiceEnhancer`? This would make it more self-contained.

Yes, that would be best.

It's nearly release time! Final confirmation ...

If you think this is, or will be in a mergeable state in the next few days, with comments addressed, and you want the jena-extras module to go it, then great.  It'll be "experimental" in the release notes anyway to give space for refinement.

If you prefer to wait a cycle (bugs, improvements pending,...) - that is fine - whatever works best for you.

> > Should I move all IRIs introduced by the plugin to that namespace? - e.g. `se:DatasetServiceEnhancer` instead of `ja:DatasetServiceEnhancer`? This would make it more self-contained.
> 
> Yes, that would be best.

Done (a bit earlier today).

> It's nearly release time! Final confirmation ...

I think I can address the remaining open issues until tonight followed by a final round of testing tomorrow (which hopefully does not reveal any serious regressions introduced by the cleanup).

We have used/tested the module internally for our use cases for a while now and all encountered issues were ironed out - so it should be ready for an experimental release for gathering additional feedback and possibly also issue reports.

@afs - thanks for the hint - 

I am trying e.g:
[count of beer instances in wikidata](https://confident.dbis.rwth-aachen.de/jena/wikidata?query=%23%20Count%20all%20items%20with%20the%20given%20type%0A%23%20Q44%3Abeer%0APREFIX%20rdf%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns%23%3E%0APREFIX%20rdfs%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema%23%3E%0APREFIX%20schema%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//schema.org/%3E%0APREFIX%20wd%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.wikidata.org/entity/%3E%0APREFIX%20wdt%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.wikidata.org/prop/direct/%3E%0APREFIX%20wikibase%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//wikiba.se/ontology%23%3E%0APREFIX%20xsd%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema%23%3E%0A%0ASELECT%20%28COUNT%20%28DISTINCT%20%3Fitem%29%20AS%20%3Fcount%29%0AWHERE%0A%7B%0A%20%20%23%20instance%20of%20beer%0A%20%20%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP31%20wd%3AQ44.%0A%7D)

and hoped:
[beer instance count with styleseheet](https://confident.dbis.rwth-aachen.de/jena/wikidata?output=xml&stylesheet=%2Fxml-to-html.xsl&query=%23%20Count%20all%20items%20with%20the%20given%20type%0A%23%20Q44%3Abeer%0APREFIX%20rdf%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns%23%3E%0APREFIX%20rdfs%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema%23%3E%0APREFIX%20schema%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//schema.org/%3E%0APREFIX%20wd%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.wikidata.org/entity/%3E%0APREFIX%20wdt%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.wikidata.org/prop/direct/%3E%0APREFIX%20wikibase%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//wikiba.se/ontology%23%3E%0APREFIX%20xsd%3A%20%3Chttp%3A//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema%23%3E%0A%0ASELECT%20%28COUNT%20%28DISTINCT%20%3Fitem%29%20AS%20%3Fcount%29%0AWHERE%0A%7B%0A%20%20%23%20instance%20of%20beer%0A%20%20%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP31%20wd%3AQ44.%0A%7D)

would work but i get:
```
XML-Verarbeitungsfehler: Syntax-Fehler
Adresse: https://confident.dbis.rwth-aachen.de/xml-to-html.xsl
Zeile Nr. 1, Spalte 50:
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
-------------------------------------------------^
```

That's an HTML document - it says two lines further down `<title>404 Not Found</title>`.

`https://confident.dbis.rwth-aachen.de/` is a gateway proxy (Apache httpd) so it will need to route the request to Fuseki and Fuseki will need to have that file in-place or the server have the file itself. 

`xml-to-html.xsl` turns XML into HTML - e.g. at http://www.sparql.org/sparql.html

Example file: http://www.sparql.org/xml-to-html.xsl

No need to paste 60-70 line query string - any short SELECT query will work for getting setup.

>When uploading data ("add data") there is a flash of orange in the progress bar then it goes green as it advances (guess: the default is orange). Minor.

I think that's because either your data is really small, or your server is responding really fast. Here's what it looks like when I upload a ~3MB file (colors are a little off due to recording quality).

![GIFrecord_2022-08-02_203732](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/182331803-ce6700ee-a9ba-46b1-811d-318a3d232118.gif)

It has no color by default. After you have selected a file and clicked upload, it will start the upload and change the bar color to orange and increase the progress status/number. Once it reaches 100% and the upload is complete it should turn green.
Yes - it was on the local machine and a very small test file. I assumed orange was an "error indicator", not "in-progress".

> Yes - it was on the local machine and a very small test file. I assumed orange was an "error indicator", not "in-progress".

Good point! Follow-up to improve it: https://github.com/apache/jena/issues/1467

>The edit function: it is not loading the current contents of the graph when you click on the graph in the list of graph (neither default nor named). This means the edit are has no triples, and when put back the graph is empty.

Excellent feedback.

There was another issue that when you clicked on add data or edit, you could see a yellow-ish box for a very quick moment, which says that No Service was found for the graphs. That's because the page is still loading the services from the service (i.e. an HTTP request and checking if we have the gsp-rw, and other services).

I changed it and now it should display that message only after it has finished loading the graphs and indeed couldn't locate the services. Before that we should see only a normal Loading/Spinner, or a Placeholder element until the page is fully loaded.

Now for the issue you found, there were two problems. One being a JavaScript error (thanks for catching that up!), and another left-over from the Bootstrap Vue migration :open_mouth: I've removed it, fixed the JS error, and wrote an e2e test to try to prevent it from happening again :+1: 

@afs in case you haven't seen the e2e tests yet, here's what it looks like when I re-run the e2e test for the Edit function. The HTTP calls are mocks that I copied/adapted from a running Fuseki instance. It creates 11 datasets (for testing pagination), and selects the first `a` dataset, then lists the current graphs, and clicks on the graph name. Finally, it confirms the code editor contains some expected text.

![GIFrecord_2022-08-02_221041](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/182351024-3629fa99-fddd-4f0d-9be3-12bb5ecbcb57.gif)

After the test has completed, you can "go back" in time. It keeps "frames" of the UI (hidden elements in the DOM). As you scroll back in the test timeline, it shows the past of the execution, allowing you to see what was clicked, what was displayed, etc.

I'm hoping this will help us move with the UI without adding regressions in every release (No promises! JS is a really permissive language, and there are so many libs involved, even though we are trying to be minimalistic... but that's the theory :laughing: )

Ready for review again! Thanks! :wave:

>@kinow what order of PRs should we work with?

If @jamiefeiss doesn't mind, I think it'd be easier to get the #1307 in first, as that one also adds the e2e tests. Later, if needed, I can help converting this PR from Bootstrap 4 to Bootstrap 5, and help with e2e tests as well. I haven't reviewed the code yet, but if it changes the Query editor we can add some tests first to `main`, and then confirm this change doesn't add any regression.

Thanks @afs & @kinow.

I'm fine with waiting for the other PR first. Once the other PR is done, I'll get this PR up to date with main, update my code to use Bootstrap 5 and write some tests.

@afs Are there any unaddressed issues remaining? From my side am currently doing the last testing and minor fixes/cleanup, but overall the test cases as well as our fuseki setup still seems to work as expected. So it looks like I can do a final squash today.

One question is how people should get the plugin into fuseki - right now they'd have to build the plugin with the `bundle` profile.
Should there be a separate maven module that creates the fuseki bundle which is published to maven central?

Another option would be to extend the fuseki setup script with support for loading artifacts with transitive dependencies from maven central directly (e.g. using mvn dependency:get) but then the script would have to rely on the `mvn` command.

Currently, because the plugin has no other dependencies besides it should work to use the module's published jar file directly.
But this will break once any third-party dependency is added so the mechanism is brittle and should not be relied upon.

I'd say the first version is complete; besides the question about the best way to get this plugin into a fuski and any unresolved issue I might have overlooked.

Work for the next version (besides fixing any reported bugs) would be:
- Clean up the util package - some utils may make sense to add to other modules such as ARQ or maybe they even exist in places I haven't found yet.
- Find better names for some classes
- Add support for persistent caches storage. I already have a file-based implementation in my own library but it needs to be ported to the interfaces of the service enhancer plugin. Once Jena switches to non-shaded guava it would also be possible to factor the cache storage API out into it's own dependency as actually this system is jena-independent - but it relies on guava's RangeSet / RangeMap interfaces and implementations.

@afs Some time ago you mentioned that you unsubscribed from the PR stream so I am just dropping a note here as well that from my side the requested changes were implemented and the PR should be complete for a release of the experimental module.

Are you calling jena-iri directly? 

1/ (repeated from [JENA-2309](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2309))
IRIx is an abstraction layer for replaceable IRI implementations.

One such IRI3986 implementation is https://github.com/afs/x4ld/tree/main/iri4ld .
Minimal object creation - one object to record the results per parser call and `RFC3986.create` is thread-safe.

Other implementations can be plugged in.

2/
The parser pipeline uses a cache to avoid duplicate work: that changes IRI processing from being the significant cost to not the primary cost when parsing on a single thread.

https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/main/jena-arq/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/riot/system/FactoryRDFCaching.java#L62
which incidentally has the benefit of reducing memory footprint (IIRC by about a 1/3). Maybe that works in `E_IRI`.


FYI: https://github.com/tarql/tarql/pull/99 upgrades tarql to Apache Jena 4.5.0
I _tried_ to unsubscribe :-) Seems there are numerous ways GH will resubscribe people!

Adding a cache to E_IRI/IRIx should be simple and I can check how much this improves.

How does the iri4ld implementation differ from jena's current default one functionality-wise? 
In any case, having less (needless) synchronization between threads is always better.

> FYI: https://github.com/tarql/tarql/pull/99 upgrades tarql to Apache Jena 4.5.0

Good to know that its possible to compare performance of spark-based tarql to original tarql within jena4! :)
Especially because then the same IRI machinery is used.


In addition, I noticed that E_BNode also causes waits due to synchronization in a SecureRandom instance. This is probably better handled as a separate issue but for now I just wanted to document it here.
My spark job's runtime (using a test mapping without iri()) jumps from ~4.5 to ~10 seconds only by adding a dummy bnode() call:
```sparql
CONSTRUCT { <urn:example:s> <urn:example:p> ?a, ?b, ?c } # ... 16 columns in total
FROM <file:data.csv>
WHERE { BIND(bnode(?a) AS ?foobar) }
```

The same job with tarql/jena2 executes somewhere between 50-60 sec where with bnode it seems to tend more towards 60sec - so in single thread processing the effect is less visible. It seems that threads competing for the bnode call is also a bottleneck.

> How does the iri4ld implementation differ from jena's current default one functionality-wise?

Javadoc has the operations described:
https://github.com/afs/x4ld/blob/main/iri4ld/src/main/java/org/seaborne/rfc3986/RFC3986.java

An Jena IRIProvider:
https://gist.github.com/afs/a0bf740d1bd1fde283eabeab8b4ddb67

It is a java-coded parser for RFC 3986. The parser is a single file (`IRI3986`), written with efficiency in-mind. No sub-parsers or tokenizers.

jena-iri is a general system for IRIs. It is complicated to build.

iri4ld simple to build and provides the operations needed for linked data. Like jena-iri, it is independent of the Jena RDF codebase. iri4ld has less in the the way of extras not used by Jena. 

The parser is IRI3986.java - all URIs (except it works in Java unicode strings so RFC 3987).

It has some additional scheme specific rule support for the common schemes: it covers "http:", "https:", "did:", "file:" "urn:uuid:", "urn:", "uuid:" (which is not official) and "example:" (RFC 7595).

The parsers generate blank nodes by allocating a UUID once at the start of a parser run, then xor'ing the label into the random number. Unlabelled blank nodes get a not-writable label (it has a 0 byte in it) allocated from a counter.

IRIx is not the place to put a cache. IRIx is general IRI machinery for any purpose.

The session is provided by an FactoryRDF (FactoryRDFCaching extends FactoryRDFStd implements FactoryRDF). The cache is then of NodeURIs.

> GitHub Actions

Go for it. We have some actions (e.g. mac testing).

The thing to watch is that all clones of the repo also get the actions.

Jena's current actions are manually run:

1. automatic actions risks hitting the cloning GH user's account on cloned repos. Oops.
1. it's a waste to run these additional tests automatically. We have ASF Jenkins all setup to trigger and these jobs don't get inherited. For a java project, running one on-push job and a few regular (e.g. weekly) jobs is more than enough.

>Go for it. We have some actions (e.g. mac testing).

Perfect, thanks @afs !

>The thing to watch is that all clones of the repo also get the actions.
>
>Jena's current actions are manually run:
>
>    automatic actions risks hitting the cloning GH user's account on cloned repos. Oops.

Maybe we could control where the jobs run. e.g.: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/26704#discussioncomment-3252979 & https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#jobsjob_idif

```
# ...
name: jena-ui
on: [push, workflow_dispatch]
jobs:
  build-ui:
    if: github.repository == apache/jena
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - ...
      - ...
 
#...
```

Or users could disable the actions in their forks.

Or we can change the trigger event of GH Actions (see below).

>    it's a waste to run these additional tests automatically. We have ASF Jenkins all setup to trigger and these jobs don't get inherited. For a java project, running one on-push job and a few regular (e.g. weekly) jobs is more than enough.

That's a good point.

I think we can also control it. For example, the project I worked today only builds for code pushed to the `main` branch, or to pull requests created against the `main` branch: https://github.com/kinow/cwlviewer/blob/f1091b4ad96236be4eb78df8451e27a81fdb972a/.github/workflows/ci-build.yml#L3-L9

My fork has not run any GH Actions, even though I created several PR's against the main repository: https://github.com/kinow/cwlviewer/actions/

Because I never created a PR on my fork to the main branch of my repository. I haven't tried it but I believe if I did that, it would trigger a PR on my fork - which I agree would be a waste of time & resources.

The main repository contains the Actions triggered `on: pull_request`: https://github.com/common-workflow-language/cwlviewer/pull/426/checks

And since it was a `pull_request` event, it's checking the merge commit (IIUC what the code will look like after it's merged): https://github.com/actions/checkout/issues/15#issuecomment-524093065 (that can be controlled too)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/184609694-3e6584f3-6d7d-43e6-b4aa-144c24720056.png)

I have seen the Jenkins jobs in the ASF Jenkins, but I will confess that I rarely verify the status there. I normally run things locally manually, but occasionally I forget and find that my branches are broken. Normally I find it before calling for a final review.

Maybe we could have Jenkins pushing notifications to GH pull requests in the future about the job status? :grimacing: That way I would fix my PR's sooner.

Let me know if you'd like this e2e GH actions to run only against `main` as in the `cwlviewer` case, or manually, and I'll update this PR. Thanks Andy!!!

On the theme of prototype but making it context sensitive, not static either-or, and more RDF-y:

That concept can be extended with an intermediate:

```
<#fresh> a ja:NewInstance ;
    ja:prototype <#description>;
    .
```
i.e. the constructor for `ja:NewInstance` would make a `newItem` call to <#description> whereas direct use would make a `construct` call.

But we need Jena/Fuseki use cases first. Avoid over engineering!

It would help me when trying to jump between several different PRs and issues (include RDF Delta):

1. Use "GH-" (capitals) in commits - having a common style makes grepping the commits logs easier.
2. Tidy the commits to what is important when looking back at this

You may think these are trivial - but for me, juggling multiple PRs and issues, common forms help.

>Adding to maven-clean-plugin is possible but maybe this is too clean because it then requires a node install and a yarn install of about 480M.

I think that should be OK? While developing the UI I don't normally call `mvn clean`, only when I switch branches or really want to clean my maven outputs. In which case I think it's far that it cleans the `node_modules` too.

Maybe we can investigate using Yarn PnP (plug-and-play) which removes the need for the `node_modules` directory - <https://yarnpkg.com/features/pnp>

But it would still download Yarn again.

My development workflow is:

1. Check out branch
2. `yarn install`
3. `yarn run serve` or some other Yarn command
4. `git commit ...`

I only use `mvn` when testing the PR, with `mvn -Pdev`, or manually specifying targets.
